Context:
The Food and Nutrition Management program at George Brown College has been delivered successfully for over 30 years. The schedule for the program is based on a five-day week from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m., allowing students to work part-time in related health care fields. The program includes an externship in a health-care industry setting, and additional work-integrated learning experiences for students without a culinary credential.

Graduates of this nutrition program will be eligible to become members of the Canadian Society of Nutrition Management, enabling them to work as Food and Nutrition Managers in Ontario's provincially accredited health-care facilities across Canada. Career opportunities include food service supervisor, food manager, nutrition manager, diet technician, and food service director.

Required courses for the program are outlined in semesters 1 and 2. Semester 1 courses include HOSF 4010 (Management Sanitation and Safety), HOST 4003 (Menu Analysis), MGMT 4005 (Food Service Management), NUTR 4002 (Nutrition Analysis), NUTR 4013 (Clinical Nutrition I), PHSL 4001 (Basic Physiology), COMM 4012 (Leadership Communication), HOSF 1146 (Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR), and HOSF 1287 (WHMIS). Semester 2 courses include HOSF 4005 (Food Modification Lab), HOST 4001 (Facilities Design), HOST 4002 (Health Care Standards), HRM 4001 (Labour Relations), and NUTR 4023 (Clinical Nutrition II), as well as PSY 4001 (Gerontology).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Food and Nutrition Management Program (Postgraduate) H402 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about courses offered in a graduate program at the college, along with their associated program learning outcomes and tuition fees. Here is the extracted information:

Courses:
- NUTR 4023: Clinical Nutrition II
- PSY 4001: Gerontology
- COMM4022: Management Communication
- HOST4020: Work-Integrated Learning (with an asterisk, indicating a requirement for students without a culinary credential)
- EXTN4000: Health Care Industry Externship (also with an asterisk)

Program learning outcomes include the ability to plan menus, manage food handling and service, accommodate diverse clients, support professional and ethical behavior, monitor trends and changes, deliver customer service, manage department staff, manage inventory and procurement, analyze and implement improvements, plan and manage budgets, and promote food and nutrition services.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,685.00 *
- International Tuition: $18,605.00 *

* Note that these fees are for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 and are subject to change for later program starts.

* Programs start in Fall 2024

Context:
Students are required to complete up to 8-10 weeks worth of health and non-academic requirements before starting their clinical placements at the college. These requirements include providing proof of medical records such as TDAP shot, COVID-19, MMR, Varicella, Hep B blood test reports/titres, Two-Step TB Skin Test, an annual Vulnerable Sector Check, and an annual flu shot. Mask fit tests are required every two years. Students must submit all requirements by the program specific deadline to the ParaMed Placement Pass website.

COVID-19 vaccination is mandatory for students in order to complete clinical placements within facilities. Renewed annually, students are also required to have a Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed every year before entering into field or clinical placement. The process for obtaining a Vulnerable Sector Check typically takes between two to three months but can take up to eight months under some circumstances. This requirement is in place to protect the clientele of placement partner agencies, considered "vulnerable persons" under the law. Students are responsible for ensuring that their Vulnerable Sector Check covers appropriateness for individuals working with vulnerable persons.

All costs associated with the health requirements are the responsibility of the student. For more details and to download the mandatory Pre-placement health form, students can visit the Clinical Pre-placement website.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Food and Nutrition Management Program (Postgraduate) H402 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Students are required to provide a "clear" Vulnerable Sector Check for field or clinical placements. Those unable to do so will not be able to complete the program and may jeopardize their progress. Our agency partners make the final decision on allowing students to practice in their agencies.

Allergens such as nuts, dairy, and shellfish are used in practical labs. The college is sensitive to religious observances but cannot guarantee products meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosan food regulations.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students must apply via the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page for domestic student inquiries, FinAid@georgebrown.ca or Financial Aid web page for financial inquiries, and CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca for Chef School inquiries.

Contact one of George Brown College's international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page. Students can visit the campus on Discovery Days to learn more about their area of interest, get a first-hand look at facilities, and meet college representatives.

International students should check the How to Apply page for application information. No specific years or numbers are mentioned in the text.

Context: Eugene Badal is a graduate of George Brown College with an Ontario College Graduate Certificate in Food and Nutrition Management (H119 or H315 or H317 may refer to related programs). He had interactions with industry professionals who were alumni of the college and was impressed by their accomplishments. The program he attended was challenging and intense but helped him advance his career into a management role. The professors and guest speakers were practicing industry professionals who provided current and relevant industry insights. The program is accredited by the Canadian Society of Nutrition Managers (CSNM).
